title: What do you call a music without lyrics? - Quora

response.answer_text: Specifically, vocals without meaning is called ‘scat’. That’s jazzed-up terminology, or more formally known as: the euphemism for “bullshit”. The times when jazz instrumentalists are playing without even vocals, it’s called a musical ‘bridge’, or ‘interlude’. When any singer is improvising vocals without reading specific lyrics it’s called ad-lib, and a random musical ad-lib without instrumental cues would be a chant or rhythm. A constant or periodic rhythm which varies independent of all known orthography is called a signal. A musical signal with no discernible pattern at all is called audible noise. Audible noise is created by alternating rarified and compressed pockets of a substance called matter, creating harmonics. Absence of conjoined matter is called space. Absence of harmonics in space is called silence. During musical movements, all silence is called ‘rest’. Finally, orthographic musical symbols suggestive of opus title, harmonic frequency, tempo, ad-lib, rest or silence are not considered as being “lyrics”, even in the presence of a mute, silent, or resting vocalist. A musician who does not vocalize is called an interpretive dancer. An interpretive dancer who attempts to communicate lyrically is called a pantomime or mime. A mime may use a prearranged construct of movements or silent instruments to mimic unspoken language which is representative of language but “without lyrics” is employing a set of signals called ‘semaphore’. Whether or not semaphore is any type of “music” depends on the subjective opinion of its observer, but semaphore is undoubtedly non-lyrical.
